comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Say, its only a paper moon Sailing over a cardboard sea But it wouldn't be make-believe If you believed in me Yes, it's only a canvas sky Hanging over a muslin tree But it wouldn't be make-believe If you believed in me Without your love It's a honky-tonk parade Without your love It's a melody played in a penny arcade It's a Barnum and Bailey world Just as phony as it can be But it wouldn't be make-believe If you believed in me.
Arlen / Harburg / Rose (1933) youtu.be/ndxAZfJxfy8

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] I know what song I'm going to have in my head all day! (And I'm not complaining! :)) Penny
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] ! www.newspapers.com/newspage/40266552/ this 1915 Huntington Press theatre column reference maybe sheds some light: "AUSTRALIAN WHIP SPINNERS The vaudeville and picture shows at the Huntington theatre will begin the week, tomorrow night, with an act by Ellis and Ellis, Australian Whip Spinners eccentric dancers and acrobats." ...possibly them...a couple of other Google hits suggest they might have still been performing in the US in the 1920s...

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Well found, we couldn't find anything much on this act. We presumed they were performing in England as most of Ms Kerr's ephemera in this collection is from the UK.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] Yes, I suspect Kerr might have encountered them during her time in the UK pre WW1.
